byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

abstract: Investigators say unfamiliarity with area and lack of experience working together contributed to American and Afghan forces' attack on Doctors Without Borders hospital in northern Afghanistan city of Kunduz; strike may have stemmed from drawdown of American troops in Afghanistan and hasty relocation of forces.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. airstrike against a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed at least 22 staff members was approved by forces normally assigned to other parts of Asia.

headline.main: Hospital Attack Fueled by Units New to Kunduz
headline.print_headline: Hospital Strike Fueled by Units New to Kunduz

snippet: The U.S. airstrike against a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed at least 22 staff members was approved by forces normally assigned to other parts of Asia.
